questions.RationaleCorrect: Supply chain security depends on verifying what you build and what you consume. Signed builds prove integrity, SBOMs provide transparency into dependencies, and controlled repositories prevent unauthorized injection of artifacts.
questions.RationaleB: Enables attacker insertion.
questions.RationaleC: Reduces detection of malicious changes.
questions.RationaleD: Leads to credential theft and pipeline compromise.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “availability” in the CIA triad?
questions.C: Ensuring systems and data are accessible when needed
questions.RationaleCorrect: Availability is about uptime and usability: redundancy, failover, capacity planning, DDoS protection, and disaster recovery. It ensures users can access resources when required.
questions.RationaleA: Confidentiality.
questions.RationaleB: Integrity.
questions.RationaleD: Non-repudiation/accountability.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports confidentiality of stored database fields such as credit card numbers?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Sensitive fields benefit from encryption/tokenization because protection travels with the data. This reduces exposure even if broader systems are accessed. Tokenization is especially common for payment data to reduce PCI scope.
questions.RationaleB: More logs can increase exposure if not controlled.
questions.RationaleC: Disabling access control is catastrophic.
questions.RationaleD: Telnet is insecure and unrelated.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting credential stuffing?
questions.A: Monitoring authentication logs for unusual failed login patterns and source IPs
questions.RationaleCorrect: Credential stuffing appears as many login attempts across many accounts, often from a few IPs or botnets, sometimes with distinct user-agent patterns. Authentication logs and analytics are the primary detection method.
questions.RationaleD: Storage resilience, unrelated.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing session hijacking?
questions.A: Use TLS, secure cookies, short session lifetimes, and token binding where available
questions.RationaleCorrect: Session hijacking succeeds when session tokens are stolen or reused. TLS prevents interception, secure cookie flags reduce theft via web attacks, short lifetimes limit reuse window, and binding techniques reduce token reuse on other clients.
questions.RationaleB: Makes interception easy.
questions.RationaleC: Eliminates identity separation; massive security risk.
questions.RationaleD: URLs leak via logs, referrers, and browser history.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized configuration changes in production systems?
questions.A: Change management with approvals and documented baselines
questions.B: Allowing admins to change anything without review
questions.RationaleCorrect: Formal change management reduces outages and security misconfigurations by requiring review, approval, testing, and rollback planning. Baselines ensure you can detect drift and return to known good states.
questions.RationaleB: Encourages mistakes and abuse.
questions.RationaleC: Removes visibility and accountability.
questions.RationaleD: Weakens authentication and increases compromise risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting against rogue DHCP servers?
questions.RationaleCorrect: DHCP snooping filters untrusted DHCP messages and prevents rogue servers from assigning malicious network configuration (like attacker-controlled gateways/DNS). This is the direct network control for rogue DHCP.
questions.RationaleB: Data protection technique.
questions.RationaleC: Storage resilience.
questions.RationaleD: Encryption algorithm; unrelated to DHCP infrastructure control.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “risk mitigation”?
questions.B: Implementing controls to reduce likelihood or impact
questions.RationaleCorrect: Mitigation reduces risk by reducing probability (hardening, patching) and/or reducing impact (segmentation, backups). It is the most common treatment strategy.
questions.RationaleA: Risk acceptance.
questions.RationaleC: Risk transfer.
questions.RationaleD: Risk avoidance.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized physical entry after business hours?
questions.A: Access control system with schedules and badge logging
questions.RationaleCorrect: A scheduled access control system enforces time-based restrictions (who can enter when) and logs entry attempts. This provides both prevention and accountability.
questions.RationaleB: Removes the control.
questions.RationaleC: Defeats the control entirely.
questions.RationaleD: Eliminates accountability and increases unauthorized access risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports identifying whether a process initiated an outbound connection on a workstation?
questions.RationaleCorrect: To determine which process initiated a connection, you need host-level visibility: process name, PID, command line, parent process, and network socket metadata. Endpoint logs/EDR provide that. Network-only sources typically cannot definitively map to the originating process.
questions.RationaleB: DNS logs show name lookups, not the initiating process.
questions.RationaleC: RAID logs are storage events.
questions.RationaleD: Printer logs are irrelevant.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST explains why organizations perform business impact analysis (BIA)?
questions.B: To determine critical functions, dependencies, and impact of disruptions
questions.RationaleCorrect: BIA is the foundation for continuity planning. It identifies what must be restored first, acceptable downtime (RTO), acceptable data loss (RPO), and key dependencies. Without a BIA, disaster recovery becomes guesswork.
questions.RationaleA: That is penetration testing.
questions.RationaleC: That is malware research/AV development.
questions.RationaleD: Password complexity is authentication policy, unrelated to operational impact analysis.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST explains why organizations use multi-factor authentication (MFA) in Zero Trust architectures?
questions.A: MFA replaces the need for network segmentation
questions.B: MFA compensates for stolen or weak credentials
questions.D: MFA removes the need for monitoring
questions.RationaleCorrect: Zero Trust assumes credentials will eventually be compromised. MFA adds an additional verification factor that an attacker is unlikely to possess, significantly reducing the usefulness of stolen passwords. This directly aligns with Zero Trust’s “never trust, always verify” principle.
questions.RationaleA: MFA does not replace segmentation; they address different attack paths.
questions.RationaleC: MFA reduces risk but cannot eliminate insider threats entirely.
questions.RationaleD: Monitoring is still essential even with MFA.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring that cryptographic keys are rotated regularly?
questions.RationaleCorrect: A key management policy defines how keys are generated, stored, rotated, revoked, and destroyed. Regular rotation limits exposure if a key is compromised and supports cryptographic hygiene.
questions.RationaleB: AUP governs user behavior, not cryptographic lifecycle.
questions.RationaleC: IR plans deal with response after incidents.
questions.RationaleD: Classification defines sensitivity, not key handling.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “defense evasion” in attacker behavior?
questions.B: Attempting to avoid detection by security controls
questions.RationaleCorrect: Defense evasion includes techniques attackers use to bypass, disable, or evade security tools (obfuscation, disabling logging, living-off-the-land). This concept is central to adversary behavior analysis.
questions.RationaleA: That is initial access.
questions.RationaleC: That is part of exfiltration or impact phases.
questions.RationaleD: That is privilege escalation.

questions.Question: Which control BEST supports preventing unauthorized access if a laptop is stolen?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Full disk encryption ensures data at rest remains unreadable without authentication. Physical theft without decryption keys does not result in data compromise.
questions.RationaleA: VLANs protect network traffic, not stolen devices.
questions.RationaleC: Load balancing improves availability.
questions.RationaleD: SIEM provides visibility, not prevention on a stolen device.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting abnormal access patterns such as impossible travel?
questions.RationaleCorrect: UEBA correlates identity, location, time, and behavior to detect anomalies such as logins from distant locations in impossible timeframes.
questions.RationaleB: RAID is storage resilience.
questions.RationaleC: NAT is address translation.
questions.RationaleD: DLP focuses on data leakage, not behavioral analysis.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “privilege escalation”?
questions.B: Increasing permissions beyond what was initially granted
questions.RationaleCorrect: Privilege escalation allows attackers to gain higher-level access after initial compromise, often enabling full system control.
questions.RationaleA: That is unauthorized access, not escalation.
questions.RationaleC: That is interception.
questions.RationaleD: That is traffic manipulation.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting against malicious insiders?
questions.A: Least privilege, logging, and separation of duties
questions.RationaleCorrect: Insider risk is reduced by limiting access, ensuring actions are logged and attributable, and preventing any single individual from controlling critical processes end-to-end.
questions.RationaleB: Reduces detection and accountability.
questions.RationaleC: Removes attribution.
questions.RationaleD: Increases blast radius of misuse.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting APIs from excessive automated requests?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Rate limiting and throttling control how frequently APIs can be accessed, preventing abuse, scraping, and denial-of-service conditions.
questions.RationaleB: Tokenization protects data, not traffic volume.
questions.RationaleC: VLANs do not control API request rates.
questions.RationaleD: Disk encryption protects stored data.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “data in use”?
questions.B: Data being transmitted over a network
questions.RationaleCorrect: Data in use exists in RAM or CPU registers while being processed. This state requires specialized protections like trusted execution environments.
questions.RationaleA: Data at rest.
questions.RationaleB: Data in transit.
questions.RationaleD: Archived data at rest.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized code execution in production environments?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Allow listing ensures only explicitly approved executables and scripts can run, stopping unknown or malicious code from executing.
questions.RationaleB: Network segmentation does not stop execution.
questions.RationaleC: RAID is availability-focused.
questions.RationaleD: Data masking affects data visibility, not execution.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes a “detective administrative control”?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Reviewing footage is a detective activity, and the process of review is administrative in nature (policy/procedure-driven), not purely technical.
questions.RationaleA: Preventive administrative control.
questions.RationaleC: Technical preventive control.
questions.RationaleD: Technical confidentiality control.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports secure authentication between services in cloud-native applications?
questions.A: Short-lived service tokens and mutual TLS
questions.RationaleCorrect: Short-lived tokens reduce reuse risk, and mutual TLS ensures both services authenticate each other. This is a modern best practice for service-to-service security.
questions.RationaleB: Hardcoded secrets are easily leaked.
questions.RationaleC: Shared credentials destroy accountability.
questions.RationaleD: URL tokens leak through logs and referrers.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “availability zone” design in cloud environments?
questions.B: Physically separate data centers within a region
questions.RationaleCorrect:
Note: This question is a multiple-answer item in the source. Correct choices include B, A. The app supports one selection, so scoring uses B.
Availability zones are isolated locations within a region designed to prevent single points of failure while maintaining low latency.
questions.RationaleA: Encryption is unrelated.
questions.RationaleC: VLANs are logical, not physical separation.
questions.RationaleD: Dedicated hardware is not required for AZs.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting brute-force attacks against web applications?
questions.RationaleCorrect: WAFs can detect repeated authentication attempts, abnormal request rates, and malicious patterns targeting web apps.
questions.RationaleB: Disk encryption does not detect attacks.
questions.RationaleC: Tokenization protects data fields.
questions.RationaleD: RAID addresses disk failures.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST explains why organizations perform patch management?
questions.B: To reduce vulnerabilities and known exploit paths
questions.RationaleCorrect: Patch management closes known security flaws, reducing the likelihood attackers can exploit published vulnerabilities. It is a foundational security hygiene practice.
questions.RationaleA: Cosmetic, not security-related.
questions.RationaleC: Patching does not aim to increase latency.
questions.RationaleD: No control eliminates all risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to cloud resources based on user attributes?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Attribute-based access control evaluates user, resource, action, and environmental attributes, allowing fine-grained, context-aware decisions.
questions.RationaleB: Storage redundancy.
questions.RationaleC: Network translation.
questions.RationaleD: File transfer protocol.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring logs are retained according to legal requirements?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Retention policies define how long logs must be kept to meet legal, regulatory, and investigative requirements.
questions.RationaleB: Authentication hygiene.
questions.RationaleC: User behavior rules.
questions.RationaleD: Cryptographic controls, not retention.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports mitigating ransomware impact?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Immutable backups prevent ransomware from encrypting backups, and testing ensures recovery works when needed.
questions.RationaleB: Eliminates recovery options.
questions.RationaleC: Increases infection risk.
questions.RationaleD: Exposes backups to encryption.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring secure disposal of paper records?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Shredding destroys paper records so sensitive information cannot be reconstructed or read.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting suspicious PowerShell execution?
questions.RationaleCorrect: EDR captures command-line usage, script execution, and process relationships—critical for detecting PowerShell abuse.
questions.RationaleB: Data-at-rest protection.
questions.RationaleC: Storage events only.
questions.RationaleD: Irrelevant.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports “least privilege” in database access?
questions.B: Role-based permissions limited to required queries
questions.RationaleCorrect: RBAC with scoped permissions ensures users and applications can only perform required operations, limiting damage from compromise or error.
questions.RationaleA: Violates least privilege.
questions.RationaleC: Removes accountability.
questions.RationaleD: Reduces detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing cross-site request forgery (CSRF)?
questions.RationaleCorrect: CSRF relies on browsers automatically sending credentials. Tokens and same-site cookie attributes ensure requests are intentional and originate from the legitimate site.
questions.RationaleB: SQLi mitigation, not CSRF.
questions.RationaleC: Data-at-rest protection.
questions.RationaleD: Network segmentation, not browser behavior control.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “incident recovery”?
questions.C: Restoring systems and returning to normal operations
questions.RationaleCorrect: Recovery focuses on restoring services, validating systems, and resuming business operations after eradication.
questions.RationaleA: Identification.
questions.RationaleB: Eradication.
questions.RationaleD: Lessons learned/governance.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting data leakage through cloud file sharing?
questions.RationaleCorrect: CASB provides visibility into SaaS file sharing, and DLP policies can detect/block sensitive data exposure.
questions.RationaleB: Storage resilience.
questions.RationaleC: Address translation.
questions.RationaleD: Network segmentation.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting against credential stuffing?
questions.RationaleCorrect: MFA blocks stolen-password reuse, and rate limiting reduces automated attempts—together providing strong defense.
questions.RationaleB: Encourages reuse attacks.
questions.RationaleC: Removes detection.
questions.RationaleD: Increases blast radius.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring accountability for database changes?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Accountability requires unique identities and audit logs so actions can be traced back to a person or service.
questions.RationaleB: Removes attribution.
questions.RationaleC: Removes evidence.
questions.RationaleD: Eliminates accountability entirely.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing DNS spoofing?
questions.RationaleCorrect: DNSSEC signs DNS records, allowing resolvers to verify authenticity and integrity, preventing spoofed responses.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting sensitive data in analytics environments?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Analytics often require realistic data structures without exposing real sensitive values. Tokenization/masking balances usability and confidentiality.
questions.RationaleB: Weakens security.
questions.RationaleC: Exposes data.
questions.RationaleD: Increases breach impact.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports reducing attack surface on servers?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Every running service is a potential entry point. Reducing what runs reduces vulnerabilities and exploitation paths.
questions.RationaleB: Increases attack surface.
questions.RationaleC: Removes accountability.
questions.RationaleD: Reduces detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting unauthorized changes to infrastructure-as-code templates?
questions.A: Version control with reviews and audit logs
questions.RationaleCorrect: IaC security depends on controlled changes. Version control with review processes ensures unauthorized modifications are detected and prevented.
questions.RationaleB: Removes change tracking.
questions.RationaleC: Exposes secrets.
questions.RationaleD: Eliminates accountability.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing attackers from exploiting known vulnerabilities?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Patching closes known security holes. Many real-world breaches exploit unpatched vulnerabilities.
questions.RationaleD: Network design, not vulnerability closure.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring encryption keys are not exposed to application memory?
questions.RationaleCorrect: HSMs perform cryptographic operations internally so keys never leave protected hardware, reducing exposure even if application memory is compromised.
questions.RationaleB: Storage redundancy.
questions.RationaleC: Address translation.
questions.RationaleD: Network segmentation.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting command-and-control traffic?
questions.RationaleCorrect: C2 traffic often shows unusual patterns, destinations, or protocols. IDS and traffic analysis are designed to detect such anomalies.
questions.RationaleB: Data-at-rest protection.
questions.RationaleC: Data field protection.
questions.RationaleD: Storage resilience.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring compliance with privacy regulations?
questions.A: Data minimization, classification, and access controls
questions.RationaleCorrect: Privacy compliance relies on collecting only needed data, classifying it correctly, restricting access, and enforcing retention limits.
questions.RationaleB: Violates privacy principles.
questions.RationaleC: Removes oversight.
questions.RationaleD: Violates retention and minimization requirements.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “identity federation”?
questions.B: Trusting an external identity provider for authentication
questions.RationaleCorrect: Federation allows users to authenticate once with an IdP and access multiple services without re-creating accounts.
questions.RationaleA: Insecure and incorrect.
questions.RationaleC: Removes security.
questions.RationaleD: Opposite of federation.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting insider data exfiltration?
questions.RationaleCorrect: UEBA detects abnormal behavior, and DLP identifies sensitive data movement. Together they address insider misuse effectively.
questions.RationaleB: Storage redundancy.
questions.RationaleC: Network segmentation only.
questions.RationaleD: Storage optimization.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring recovery from accidental deletion?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Backups provide the ability to restore data after deletion, corruption, or ransomware.
questions.RationaleB: Data protection, not recovery. C/D: Networking constructs.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing man-in-the-middle attacks on web traffic?
questions.RationaleCorrect: TLS encrypts traffic and authenticates servers via certificates, preventing attackers from intercepting or altering communications.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports enforcing security policies on unmanaged devices?
questions.A: Conditional access with device posture checks
questions.RationaleCorrect: Conditional access evaluates device state before granting access, limiting risk from unmanaged or non-compliant devices.
questions.RationaleB: Increases risk.
questions.RationaleC: Weakens authentication.
questions.RationaleD: Removes control entirely.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “threat intelligence”?
questions.B: Information about adversaries, tactics, and indicators
questions.RationaleCorrect: Threat intelligence informs defensive decisions by providing insight into attacker behavior, tools, and indicators of compromise.
questions.RationaleA: That is prevention/response.
questions.RationaleC: Data protection.
questions.RationaleD: Data governance.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized database access?
questions.A: Strong authentication, authorization, and network restrictions
questions.RationaleCorrect: Layered controls ensure only authorized users and systems can access databases, reducing compromise risk.
questions.RationaleB: Reduces recovery.
questions.RationaleC: Removes detection.
questions.RationaleD: Eliminates accountability.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting anomalous outbound data transfers?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Exfiltration often manifests as abnormal outbound traffic. Monitoring and analytics are required to identify it.
questions.RationaleD: Storage resilience.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports reducing the impact of credential compromise?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Least privilege limits what attackers can do, and MFA reduces the likelihood stolen credentials can be used.
questions.RationaleB: Increases blast radius.
questions.RationaleC: Reduces detection.
questions.RationaleD: Magnifies damage.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring systems remain available during hardware failure?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Availability depends on eliminating single points of failure through redundant components and automatic failover.
questions.RationaleD: Authentication hygiene.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports secure management of secrets in applications?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Secrets managers centralize storage, access control, rotation, and auditing of secrets, reducing exposure and misuse.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting unauthorized physical access attempts?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Physical access systems log badge attempts and trigger alarms on failures, enabling detection and investigation.
questions.RationaleB: Data protection.
questions.RationaleC: Storage resilience.
questions.RationaleD: Network segmentation.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing configuration drift?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Baselines plus monitoring ensure systems remain in approved states and deviations are detected quickly.
questions.RationaleB: Removes change tracking.
questions.RationaleC: Encourages drift.
questions.RationaleD: Eliminates reference state.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting phishing campaigns?
questions.A: Email filtering, user reports, and log analysis
questions.RationaleCorrect: Phishing detection relies on layered controls: technical filters, human reporting, and analytics to identify patterns.
questions.RationaleB: Data-at-rest protection.
questions.RationaleC: Storage resilience.
questions.RationaleD: Network translation.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring integrity of software updates?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Signatures allow systems to verify that updates are authentic and unmodified, preventing malicious tampering.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST explains why organizations implement Zero Trust?
questions.A: To trust internal users by default
questions.B: To reduce reliance on perimeter-only defenses
questions.RationaleCorrect: Zero Trust acknowledges that perimeter defenses alone are insufficient and focuses on continuous verification, least privilege, and segmentation.
questions.RationaleA: Opposite of Zero Trust philosophy.
questions.RationaleC: Zero Trust strengthens authentication.
questions.RationaleD: It complicates, not simplifies, attacks.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized changes to security group rules in cloud environments?
questions.B: Infrastructure-as-code with version control and approvals
questions.RationaleCorrect: Managing security groups as code enforces change control, peer review, audit trails, and rollback capability. This prevents ad-hoc, undocumented rule changes that often lead to cloud breaches. IaC directly addresses misconfiguration risk, which is one of the leading cloud threats.
questions.RationaleA: Manual reviews are error-prone and do not scale.
questions.RationaleC: Disabling monitoring removes visibility and accountability.
questions.RationaleD: Shared credentials eliminate attribution and increase risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST explains why organizations encrypt backups?
questions.B: To ensure confidentiality if backup media is stolen
questions.RationaleCorrect: Backups often contain complete datasets. If stolen or accessed by unauthorized parties, unencrypted backups can lead to catastrophic data exposure. Encryption protects confidentiality even if physical or logical access is lost.
questions.RationaleA: Encryption does not reduce size.
questions.RationaleC: Encryption usually adds overhead, not speed.
questions.RationaleD: Encryption does not prevent hardware failure.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized privilege escalation in operating systems?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Privilege escalation commonly exploits unpatched vulnerabilities. Least privilege limits what compromised accounts can do, while patching removes escalation paths. Together, they directly target escalation risk.
questions.RationaleB: Password length does not address local privilege exploits.
questions.RationaleC: Disabling logs removes detection.
questions.RationaleD: Allowing installs increases attack surface.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes a “logic bomb”?
questions.B: Malicious code triggered by a specific condition or time
questions.RationaleCorrect:
Note: This question is a multiple-answer item in the source. Correct choices include B, A. The app supports one selection, so scoring uses B.
Logic bombs remain dormant until a condition is met (date, event, employee termination). They are often insider-driven and difficult to detect because they appear inactive.
questions.RationaleA: That describes a worm.
questions.RationaleC: That is vishing.
questions.RationaleD: That is a denial-of-service attack.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting suspicious use of administrative credentials?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Admin accounts are high-risk. Monitoring command usage, session behavior, and access times allows detection of misuse or compromise. Visibility is essential for accountability.
questions.RationaleB: Data protection technique, not behavior detection.
questions.RationaleC: Storage resilience.
questions.RationaleD: Data-at-rest protection only.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring compliance with regulatory audit requirements?
questions.A: Documented policies, controls, and audit logs
questions.RationaleCorrect: Audits rely on evidence. Policies show intent, controls show implementation, and logs show enforcement. Without documentation and logs, compliance cannot be demonstrated.
questions.RationaleB: Eliminates evidence.
questions.RationaleC: Destroys accountability.
questions.RationaleD: Verbal procedures are not auditable.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing lateral movement in enterprise networks?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Lateral movement relies on flat networks and excessive permissions. Segmentation restricts paths, and least privilege limits what attackers can access after compromise.
questions.RationaleB: Enables lateral movement.
questions.RationaleC: Removes internal barriers.
questions.RationaleD: Increases blast radius.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting compromised service accounts?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Service accounts have predictable behavior. UEBA can detect deviations such as unusual login times, locations, or access patterns that indicate compromise.
questions.RationaleB: Protects stored data.
questions.RationaleC: Storage redundancy.
questions.RationaleD: Network translation.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting sensitive data during transmission between microservices?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Mutual TLS encrypts traffic and authenticates both client and server, ensuring only trusted services communicate. This is critical in microservice architectures.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “attack surface reduction”?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Reducing attack surface means minimizing exposed functionality and access points. Fewer services and permissions mean fewer opportunities for exploitation.
questions.RationaleA: Increases exposure.
questions.RationaleC: Increases risk.
questions.RationaleD: Complexity often creates security gaps.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized firmware changes?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Secure boot verifies firmware integrity at startup, and signing ensures updates are authentic. This protects systems at the lowest level of trust.
questions.RationaleB: Leaves vulnerabilities unpatched.
questions.RationaleC: Allows malicious firmware.
questions.RationaleD: Removes accountability.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting brute-force SSH login attempts?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Repeated failed login attempts and unusual source IPs are visible in auth logs. IDS can correlate and alert on these patterns.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports secure handling of secrets in CI/CD pipelines?
questions.A: Secrets vaults with access controls and rotation
questions.RationaleCorrect: CI/CD pipelines are high-value targets. Vaults centralize secret storage, enforce access control, enable rotation, and reduce exposure in code and logs.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring systems remain operational during power failures?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Power redundancy ensures availability during outages. UPS handles short interruptions; generators handle extended failures.
questions.RationaleC: Protects against disk failure, not power loss.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “shadow IT”?
questions.B: Unauthorized applications or services used without IT approval
questions.RationaleCorrect: Shadow IT bypasses governance, creating security and compliance blind spots. CASBs and discovery tools are often used to address it.
questions.RationaleA: Authorized systems are not shadow IT.
questions.RationaleC: Firmware malware is unrelated.
questions.RationaleD: Encrypted backups are good practice.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting data leakage via USB devices?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Endpoint controls can restrict USB usage, and DLP can inspect data transfers, preventing or detecting exfiltration via removable media.
questions.RationaleB: Storage resilience.
questions.RationaleC: Address translation.
questions.RationaleD: Network segmentation only.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting against credential harvesting malware?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Credential harvesting malware steals passwords. MFA makes stolen credentials insufficient, while endpoint protection helps detect and block the malware itself.
questions.RationaleB: Weakens security.
questions.RationaleC: Increases exposure.
questions.RationaleD: Removes detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “business continuity planning”?
questions.B: Ensuring critical business functions continue during disruptions
questions.RationaleCorrect: Business continuity focuses on keeping the business running, not just IT systems. This includes people, processes, facilities, and suppliers.
questions.RationaleA: That is disaster recovery, not full continuity.
questions.RationaleC: Security operations task.
questions.RationaleD: Authentication policy.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized SaaS access from unmanaged devices?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Conditional access evaluates device compliance, location, and risk before granting access, reducing exposure from unmanaged devices.
questions.RationaleB: Removes control.
questions.RationaleC: Weakens authentication.
questions.RationaleD: Eliminates accountability.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting unauthorized changes in cloud IAM policies?
questions.RationaleCorrect: IAM changes are high impact. Monitoring and logs provide visibility and alerting on unauthorized or risky permission changes.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing attackers from abusing stolen API keys?
questions.A: Short-lived keys, rotation, and scope limitation
questions.RationaleCorrect: Limiting key lifetime and scope reduces the window and impact of misuse. Rotation ensures compromised keys are quickly invalidated.
questions.RationaleD: Removes detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing ransomware spread within a network?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Ransomware spreads laterally. Segmentation limits propagation, and least privilege reduces access to additional systems.
questions.RationaleB: Accelerates spread.
questions.RationaleC: Eliminates recovery.
questions.RationaleD: Enables widespread infection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring integrity of log data?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Hashing detects tampering, and secure storage prevents unauthorized modification. Integrity is critical for investigations and compliance.
questions.RationaleB: No integrity protection.
questions.RationaleC: Breaks correlation and trust.
questions.RationaleD: Violates confidentiality.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting anomalous outbound traffic patterns?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Exfiltration and C2 traffic often appear as abnormal outbound patterns. Monitoring and analytics are required to identify them.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to privileged commands on network devices?
questions.RationaleCorrect: TACACS+ supports granular command-level authorization and accounting, ensuring admins can only execute approved commands.
questions.RationaleC: Legacy monitoring protocol.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing data exposure in non-production environments?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Non-production environments often have weaker controls. Masking or synthetic data preserves usability while protecting sensitive information.
questions.RationaleB: High breach risk.
questions.RationaleC: Removes protection.
questions.RationaleD: Expands exposure.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring compliance with the principle of least privilege over time?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Access needs change over time. Reviews ensure permissions remain appropriate and excess rights are removed.
questions.RationaleB: Leads to privilege creep.
questions.RationaleC: Removes oversight.
questions.RationaleD: Removes accountability.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting malicious scheduled tasks?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Attackers often use scheduled tasks for persistence. Monitoring and baselining allow detection of unauthorized or suspicious tasks.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting sensitive information in memory?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Secure enclaves protect data while in use, isolating memory from the OS and hypervisor, addressing advanced attack scenarios.
questions.RationaleB: Protects data at rest.
questions.RationaleC: Protects stored values, not runtime memory.
questions.RationaleD: Network control only.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring rapid recovery from application failure?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Failover ensures availability by automatically shifting workloads to healthy components with minimal downtime.
questions.RationaleD: Authentication policy.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes “risk acceptance”?
questions.C: Acknowledging and tolerating risk without additional controls
questions.RationaleCorrect: Risk acceptance means leadership knowingly accepts the risk because mitigation is too costly or impact is low.
questions.RationaleA: Risk avoidance.
questions.RationaleB: Risk mitigation.
questions.RationaleD: Risk transfer.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized software updates?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Digital signatures verify authenticity and integrity of updates, preventing malicious tampering.
questions.RationaleD: Removes accountability.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting insider abuse of databases?
questions.A: Database activity monitoring and audit logs
questions.RationaleCorrect: Monitoring queries, access patterns, and changes provides visibility into misuse by authorized users.
questions.RationaleB: Storage resilience.
questions.RationaleC: Network translation.
questions.RationaleD: Data protection, not detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring secure remote work access?
questions.A: VPN or Zero Trust Network Access with MFA
questions.RationaleCorrect: Secure remote access requires encryption and strong authentication. ZTNA further reduces exposure by limiting access to specific apps.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized changes to DNS records?
questions.A: Role-based access and DNS change logging
questions.RationaleCorrect: DNS is critical infrastructure. Restricting who can modify records and logging changes prevents and detects tampering.
questions.RationaleB: Removes evidence.
questions.RationaleC: Removes accountability.
questions.RationaleD: Exposes DNS to abuse.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting malware that uses living-off-the-land techniques?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Living-off-the-land attacks use legitimate tools. Behavioral EDR detects misuse patterns rather than relying on signatures.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting sensitive logs from unauthorized access?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Logs often contain sensitive data. Encryption protects confidentiality, and access controls restrict who can view them.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized cloud resource creation?
questions.A: IAM policies with least privilege and monitoring
questions.RationaleCorrect: Restricting permissions and monitoring usage prevents rogue resource creation that can increase cost and risk.
questions.RationaleB: Extremely dangerous.
questions.RationaleC: Removes detection.
questions.RationaleD: Violates least privilege.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting phishing attempts before users click links?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Gateways analyze sender reputation, content, and links to block phishing before it reaches users.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring accountability for system changes?
questions.A: Change management with approvals and logging
questions.RationaleCorrect: Formal change processes ensure changes are authorized, documented, and traceable to individuals.
questions.RationaleB: No attribution.
questions.RationaleC: No visibility.
questions.RationaleD: No audit trail.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting against insider sabotage?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Insider sabotage requires opportunity. Separation of duties limits unilateral actions, and monitoring increases deterrence and detection.
questions.RationaleB: Removes evidence.
questions.RationaleC: Removes accountability.
questions.RationaleD: Maximizes damage potential.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting suspicious authentication attempts across multiple systems?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Only centralized correlation can identify patterns across systems, such as credential stuffing or lateral movement.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring encrypted communications for APIs?
questions.RationaleCorrect: TLS encrypts API traffic and provides integrity and authentication.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to backups?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Backups must be protected like production data. Access control restricts who can read them; encryption protects confidentiality.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting abnormal database queries?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Unusual query volume, timing, or structure can indicate compromise or misuse. Monitoring provides that visibility.
questions.RationaleB: Storage.
questions.RationaleC: Network translation.
questions.RationaleD: Data protection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting credentials stored on endpoints?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Secure credential storage isolates secrets from user processes, reducing credential dumping attacks.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting unauthorized privilege use?
questions.A: Audit logs and alerting on privileged actions
questions.RationaleCorrect: Privileged actions must be logged and monitored to detect abuse or compromise.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to cloud management consoles?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Management consoles control infrastructure. Strong authentication and access conditions significantly reduce takeover risk.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: No detection.
questions.RationaleD: Extremely dangerous.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring systems recover quickly after incidents?
questions.A: Tested incident response and recovery plans
questions.RationaleCorrect: Plans that are tested ensure staff know procedures, dependencies are understood, and recovery objectives are achievable.
questions.RationaleB: Eliminates recovery.
questions.RationaleC: Increases confusion and risk.
questions.RationaleD: Prevents improvement.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST summarizes the goal of security monitoring?
questions.B: To detect, analyze, and respond to security events
questions.RationaleCorrect: Monitoring provides visibility, enabling timely detection and response. It complements preventive controls and reduces dwell time.
questions.RationaleA: Data without analysis has little value.
questions.RationaleC: Risk cannot be eliminated entirely.
questions.RationaleD: Monitoring complements, not replaces, prevention.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting unauthorized access to cloud storage services?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Cloud storage access logs record who accessed data, from where, and what actions were taken. Continuous monitoring allows detection of suspicious access patterns, such as access from unexpected locations or excessive downloads, which is critical in cloud environments.
questions.RationaleB: Disk encryption protects confidentiality but does not detect access.
questions.RationaleC: RAID provides availability, not visibility.
questions.RationaleD: VLANs segment networks but do not track cloud storage access.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized deletion of critical data?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Restricting delete permissions and enabling versioning ensures only authorized users can remove data and allows recovery if deletion occurs. This directly mitigates accidental or malicious deletion.
questions.RationaleB: Eliminates recovery capability.
questions.RationaleC: Removes accountability.
questions.RationaleD: Prevents investigation and detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting anomalous login behavior across multiple cloud services?
questions.A: Centralized identity logs and SIEM correlation
questions.RationaleCorrect: Only centralized logging with correlation can reveal patterns such as repeated failures, impossible travel, or credential stuffing across services.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting sensitive data stored in object storage?
questions.A: Encryption at rest and access control policies
questions.RationaleCorrect: Encryption protects confidentiality if storage is accessed unlawfully, and access policies restrict who can read or modify objects.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing privilege escalation in containerized environments?
questions.A: Least privilege container roles and patched base images
questions.RationaleCorrect: Containers inherit vulnerabilities from base images. Least privilege limits damage, and patching removes known escalation paths.
questions.RationaleC: Removes detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting command-and-control communication from endpoints?
questions.RationaleCorrect: C2 traffic often shows unusual destinations, protocols, or timing. IDS and traffic analytics are designed to detect these patterns.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to administrative interfaces?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Administrative interfaces are high-value targets. Strong authentication and network restrictions significantly reduce attack surface.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: No detection.
questions.RationaleD: Maximizes risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting insider misuse of file shares?
questions.A: File access logs and behavior analysis
questions.RationaleCorrect: Logs reveal who accessed files and when, while behavior analysis detects unusual access volume or patterns indicative of misuse.
questions.RationaleB: Protects confidentiality at rest only.
questions.RationaleC: Storage resilience.
questions.RationaleD: Limits network paths but does not detect misuse.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting API secrets used by applications?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Secrets managers centralize storage, enforce access control, enable auditing, and rotate secrets to reduce exposure.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring integrity of audit logs?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Hashing detects tampering, and write-once storage prevents modification, ensuring logs remain trustworthy for investigations.
questions.RationaleB: No integrity protection. C/D: Remove accountability and protection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized wireless access?
questions.RationaleCorrect: WPA3 provides improved encryption and authentication, reducing risk of eavesdropping and unauthorized access.
questions.RationaleD: Removes detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting malware persistence mechanisms?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Persistence often uses registry keys, services, or scheduled tasks. Monitoring changes against baselines reveals unauthorized persistence.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to source code repositories?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Source code is sensitive intellectual property. Strong authentication and scoped roles protect against compromise and insider misuse.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: Exposes code.
questions.RationaleD: Removes visibility.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting data exfiltration over encrypted channels?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Even when content is encrypted, volume, timing, and destination analysis can reveal suspicious exfiltration.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized database schema changes?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Schema changes can break applications or expose data. Formal change control and restricted roles prevent unauthorized modifications.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: No detection.
questions.RationaleD: High error and abuse risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting sensitive configuration files?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Config files often contain secrets. Restricting access and encrypting them protects confidentiality and integrity.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting unauthorized cloud resource usage that increases costs?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Unexpected resource creation or abuse often shows up as cost anomalies. Monitoring and alerts provide early detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing replay attacks?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Nonces and timestamps ensure each authentication exchange is unique and time-bound, preventing reuse of captured traffic.
questions.RationaleD: Removes detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting compromised credentials?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Compromised credentials often result in unusual login locations, times, or access patterns that analytics can detect.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring business resilience against cyber incidents?
questions.A: Defense in depth and incident response planning
questions.RationaleCorrect: Layered controls reduce impact, and prepared response plans enable faster containment and recovery, improving resilience.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to backups stored offsite?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Offsite backups are vulnerable targets. Encryption protects confidentiality, and access controls restrict who can retrieve them.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting phishing emails that bypass initial filters?
questions.RationaleCorrect: No filter is perfect. User reports combined with SOC investigation enable rapid detection and response to missed phishing attempts.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized modifications to application code?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Code signing verifies integrity, and access controls restrict who can modify code, preventing tampering.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: No detection.
questions.RationaleD: High risk of error or abuse.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting unusual privilege use on servers?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Monitoring privileged actions reveals misuse or compromise that would otherwise go unnoticed.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to email accounts?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Email is a primary attack vector. MFA significantly reduces account takeover risk even if passwords are stolen.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: No detection.
questions.RationaleD: Easily compromised.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting malicious outbound DNS queries?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Malware often uses DNS for C2 or data exfiltration. Analyzing query patterns and destinations reveals suspicious activity.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized changes to firewall rules?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Firewall rules control network exposure. Restricting who can change them and tracking changes prevents misconfiguration and abuse.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: No detection.
questions.RationaleD: Extremely dangerous.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring confidentiality of data sent over public networks?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Encryption protects data from interception and eavesdropping when traversing untrusted networks.
questions.RationaleB: Local network segmentation only.
questions.RationaleC: Availability control.
questions.RationaleD: Data-at-rest/field protection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting suspicious file downloads by users?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Proxy logs show destinations and file transfers, and analysis can identify unusual or malicious download behavior.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to network devices?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Centralized AAA enforces consistent authentication, authorization, and accounting across devices, improving security and visibility.
questions.RationaleB: Insecure protocol.
questions.RationaleC: No accountability.
questions.RationaleD: No detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting abnormal resource usage on servers?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Abnormal CPU, memory, or network usage can indicate compromise. Monitoring reveals these deviations.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to sensitive reports?
questions.RationaleCorrect: RBAC ensures only users with a business need can view sensitive information.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting abnormal API usage?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Monitoring request rates, endpoints, and patterns reveals abuse, scraping, or compromise.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized changes to system time?
questions.RationaleCorrect: System time integrity is critical for logs and authentication. Restricting changes and monitoring sync prevents tampering.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: No detection.
questions.RationaleD: High risk of abuse.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting compromised IoT devices?
questions.A: Network traffic monitoring and anomaly detection
questions.RationaleCorrect: IoT devices often lack host agents. Network behavior analysis is the most effective detection method.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to virtual machines?
questions.A: Hypervisor security, IAM, and network controls
questions.RationaleCorrect: VM security depends on layered controls across identity, network, and virtualization layers.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting insider misuse of email?
questions.A: Email audit logs and behavior analysis
questions.RationaleCorrect: Logs show sending patterns, recipients, and volume. Analysis detects abnormal usage indicative of misuse.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to APIs by third parties?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Scoped tokens limit what third parties can do, reducing impact if credentials are misused.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting tampering with system binaries?
questions.RationaleCorrect: FIM detects unauthorized changes to critical binaries, a common persistence and privilege escalation technique.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized remote access?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Strong authentication and encrypted channels reduce the risk of remote compromise.
questions.RationaleB: Insecure protocol.
questions.RationaleC: No accountability.
questions.RationaleD: No detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting abnormal privilege escalation attempts?
questions.A: Audit logs and alerting on permission changes
questions.RationaleCorrect: Privilege escalation involves permission changes that must be logged and monitored to detect abuse.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting sensitive data processed by applications?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Secure coding prevents vulnerabilities, and runtime protections mitigate exploitation during execution.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting compromised administrator accounts?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Admins have predictable patterns. Deviations detected by UEBA indicate possible compromise.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized changes to cloud networking?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Cloud networking errors cause major breaches. IaC and monitoring enforce control and visibility.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: No detection.
questions.RationaleD: High error risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting malicious macro execution?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Macros execute code. Endpoint monitoring detects suspicious execution behavior.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring integrity of backups?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Hashes detect corruption or tampering, and test restores validate usability.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized changes to operating system configurations?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Baselines, restricted permissions, and monitoring ensure OS configs remain secure and authorized.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: No detection.
questions.RationaleD: High risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting data exfiltration attempts from endpoints?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Endpoint behavior combined with network analysis reveals attempts to steal and transmit data.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to SaaS applications?
questions.A: SSO with MFA and conditional access
questions.RationaleCorrect: Centralized authentication with strong controls reduces account takeover risk and improves visibility.
questions.RationaleB: No accountability.
questions.RationaleC: No detection.
questions.RationaleD: Easily compromised.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting unauthorized system changes during an incident?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Incident investigations rely on logs and forensic evidence to identify what changed, when, and by whom.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing data exfiltration from a cloud environment to unauthorized external destinations?
questions.A: Egress filtering and outbound allow lists
questions.RationaleCorrect: Egress filtering controls what outbound connections are permitted. In cloud, limiting outbound destinations (IP/FQDN allow lists), restricting protocols/ports, and monitoring egress traffic directly reduces the attacker’s ability to exfiltrate data to arbitrary systems.
questions.RationaleB: Disabling TLS makes interception easier and does not stop exfiltration.
questions.RationaleC: Allowing all outbound traffic is exactly what enables easy exfiltration.
questions.RationaleD: Password complexity does not stop a compromised host from sending data out.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting suspicious OAuth token misuse?
questions.A: Monitoring token issuance, scopes, and unusual API call patterns
questions.RationaleCorrect: OAuth abuse often appears as abnormal token issuance (new clients, unusual grant types), overly broad scopes, and strange usage patterns (mass downloads, odd endpoints, unusual times/locations). Observability into token and API telemetry is the most direct way to detect misuse.
questions.RationaleB: Protects data at rest, not token activity.
questions.RationaleC: Storage resilience, unrelated.
questions.RationaleD: VLANs don’t reveal or validate token behavior.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST mitigates the risk of an attacker using stolen refresh tokens?
questions.A: Short refresh token lifetimes with rotation and revocation
questions.RationaleCorrect: Refresh tokens are powerful because they can mint new access tokens. Short lifetimes reduce the reuse window, rotation invalidates older refresh tokens after use, and revocation capability allows immediate shutdown of compromised tokens.
questions.RationaleB: Removes your ability to detect compromise and respond.
questions.RationaleC: URLs leak via logs, browser history, and referrers.
questions.RationaleD: Indefinite validity maximizes attacker persistence.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to Kubernetes cluster administration?
questions.A: RBAC with least privilege, MFA for admins, and audit logging
questions.RationaleCorrect: Kubernetes administration is extremely high impact. RBAC scopes permissions, MFA strengthens authentication for administrative access, and audit logging provides accountability and detection.
questions.RationaleB: No attribution and high compromise impact.
questions.RationaleC: Removes critical evidence and detection.
questions.RationaleD: Violates least privilege and dramatically increases risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing exposure of secrets in container images?
questions.A: Using secrets managers and excluding secrets from images and build context
questions.B: Baking API keys into the image for convenience
questions.RationaleCorrect: Images are widely distributed and cached. If a secret enters an image layer, it is difficult to remove and often permanently exposed. Secrets should be injected at runtime via a secret store, not embedded in images.
questions.RationaleD: Public distribution increases exposure immediately.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring a compromised endpoint cannot access internal applications by default?
questions.A: Zero Trust Network Access (ZTNA) with per-app policies
questions.B: Flat network access with internal trust
questions.D: Allowing VPN access to entire subnets
questions.RationaleCorrect: ZTNA grants access to specific applications based on identity, device posture, and context. This limits lateral movement and prevents “once inside, everything is reachable” behavior.
questions.RationaleB: Flat trust enables lateral movement.
questions.RationaleC: Weakens authentication and increases compromise risk.
questions.RationaleD: Broad subnet VPN access expands blast radius.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing malicious code from entering a software build pipeline?
questions.A: Code review, signed commits, and protected branches
questions.B: Allowing direct pushes to main branch
questions.RationaleCorrect: These controls ensure changes are verified, attributable, and approved before release. Signed commits help verify author integrity, and protected branches prevent unauthorized merges.
questions.RationaleD: Removes accountability and increases insider risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting a domain hijack attempt?
questions.A: Monitoring DNS changes, registrar locks, and alerts on record modifications
questions.RationaleCorrect: Domain hijacking targets registrar credentials and DNS records. Monitoring and registrar protections (locks, MFA) detect and slow unauthorized changes, enabling rapid response.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing credential theft via phishing?
questions.RationaleCorrect: FIDO2/WebAuthn ties authentication to the legitimate origin and uses public-key cryptography, making it highly resistant to credential capture and replay on attacker-controlled sites.
questions.RationaleB: Complex passwords can still be phished.
questions.RationaleC: Often guessable or discoverable.
questions.RationaleD: Disabling TLS increases interception risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting suspicious privilege assignments in a cloud IAM system?
questions.A: Alerting on policy changes and privilege escalations in audit logs
questions.RationaleCorrect: Unauthorized privilege grants are a common cloud attack path. Audit logs show who changed what; alerting detects risky changes quickly before they are exploited further.
questions.RationaleD: Segmentation doesn’t reveal IAM modifications.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports reducing the impact of a compromised API endpoint?
questions.A: Least privilege scopes, rate limiting, and strict input validation
questions.D: Returning verbose error messages with stack traces
questions.RationaleCorrect: Scoping limits what the endpoint can do, rate limiting reduces abuse and automated exploitation, and input validation prevents injection and logic abuse. Together, they reduce both likelihood and impact.
questions.RationaleB: Makes compromise trivial.
questions.RationaleC: Enables brute force and abuse.
questions.RationaleD: Helps attackers by leaking internals.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing log injection attacks?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Log injection occurs when attacker-controlled input is written into logs and alters log meaning or hides activity. Sanitization prevents malicious characters, and structured logging (key-value/JSON) reduces ambiguity and tampering opportunities.
questions.RationaleB: Eliminates detection and forensics.
questions.RationaleC: Plaintext alone doesn’t prevent injection.
questions.RationaleD: Public access increases data exposure.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring sensitive fields are protected even if a database backup is leaked?
questions.RationaleCorrect: If attackers get a backup, field-level controls keep sensitive values protected even outside the DB environment. Tokenization can also reduce compliance scope and exposure.
questions.RationaleD: Availability/performance, unrelated to backup confidentiality.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST describes a “break-glass” account?
questions.A: A shared admin account used daily
questions.B: An emergency account with tightly controlled use for outages
questions.D: A default vendor account left enabled
questions.RationaleCorrect: Break-glass accounts exist for rare emergencies (IdP outage, lockout events). They should be heavily protected, monitored, and used only under strict procedures.
questions.RationaleA: Daily shared use is a major security anti-pattern.
questions.RationaleC: Guest accounts are not break-glass accounts.
questions.RationaleD: Default vendor accounts are a common vulnerability, not a resilience control.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing attackers from abusing default credentials on IoT devices?
questions.A: Enforcing credential changes, disabling defaults, and network isolation
questions.RationaleCorrect: Default passwords are widely known. Changing them, disabling unused accounts, patching firmware, and isolating IoT networks dramatically reduces compromise risk.
questions.RationaleB: Weakens security.
questions.RationaleC: Public exposure increases compromise likelihood.
questions.RationaleD: Unpatched firmware increases vulnerabilities.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports verifying the integrity of downloaded software?
questions.A: Hash verification from a trusted source
questions.B: Running the installer as administrator immediately
questions.RationaleCorrect: Comparing a known-good hash from a trusted source verifies the file was not tampered with or corrupted. This directly checks integrity before execution.
questions.RationaleB: Admin execution increases impact if malicious.
questions.RationaleC: Removes protection and increases risk.
questions.RationaleD: Unknown mirrors are a common supply-chain risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access due to orphaned accounts?
questions.A: Automated deprovisioning tied to HR events
questions.B: Allowing accounts to remain active indefinitely
questions.RationaleCorrect: Orphaned accounts (departed employees, role changes) are common attack paths. Automated offboarding removes access quickly and consistently, reducing human error.
questions.RationaleB: Maximizes exposure window.
questions.RationaleC: Eliminates accountability.
questions.RationaleD: Removes oversight and increases privilege creep.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting unauthorized changes to group policy (or equivalent configuration policy)?
questions.A: Audit logs, change alerts, and baseline comparison
questions.RationaleCorrect: Policy changes can rapidly weaken security. Auditing and alerting detect unauthorized modifications; baselines confirm what “should be” versus what “is.”

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing data exposure from misconfigured public cloud storage buckets?
questions.A: CSPM and restrictive bucket policies by default
questions.RationaleCorrect: This is a classic cloud breach scenario. CSPM detects misconfigurations and policy drift; secure defaults prevent accidental public exposure before it happens.
questions.RationaleB: Weakens confidentiality.
questions.RationaleC: Directly causes exposure.
questions.RationaleD: Removes visibility to detect abuse.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring the authenticity of emails claiming to be from an organization’s domain?
questions.RationaleCorrect: SPF verifies authorized sending servers, DKIM signs messages for integrity/authenticity, and DMARC enforces policy and reporting. Together they reduce spoofing and improve trust in domain-sent email.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports limiting the blast radius of a compromised identity in a cloud environment?
questions.A: Least privilege IAM roles and conditional policies
questions.RationaleCorrect: Least privilege limits what the identity can do; conditional policies (device posture, IP restrictions, MFA requirements) further constrain abuse. This directly reduces impact after compromise.
questions.RationaleB: Violates least privilege and increases blast radius.
questions.RationaleC: Root compromise is catastrophic; shared root is worse.
questions.RationaleD: Removes detection and accountability.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing credential reuse attacks across different services?
questions.A: MFA and unique passwords via password managers
questions.RationaleCorrect: Credential reuse attacks succeed when the same password works in multiple places. Password managers enable unique passwords; MFA blocks stolen-password logins.
questions.RationaleB: Expiration doesn’t prevent reuse if users recycle patterns.
questions.RationaleC: Weak and often guessable.
questions.RationaleD: Removing lockout makes brute force easier.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting unauthorized access to privileged secrets (like vault entries)?
questions.A: Vault audit logs with alerts on sensitive secret reads
questions.RationaleCorrect: Secret reads are critical events. Vault logs capture who accessed what and when; alerting detects suspicious access early before secrets are used for broader compromise.
questions.RationaleB: Protects storage, not secret access events.
questions.RationaleC: Network segmentation may limit paths but doesn’t record reads.
questions.RationaleD: Storage resilience.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting against “pass-the-hash” attacks?
questions.A: Restricting NTLM usage, enabling credential protections, and limiting lateral admin
questions.RationaleCorrect: Pass-the-hash relies on reused hashes and lateral authentication. Reducing NTLM, using credential isolation protections, and limiting admin reuse across machines significantly reduces viability.
questions.RationaleB: Weakens authentication.
questions.RationaleC: Shared local admin passwords enable rapid lateral movement.
questions.RationaleD: Unrestricted SMB increases lateral movement opportunities.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing accidental disclosure of sensitive data in chat/collaboration tools?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Collaboration platforms are common leakage points. DLP can detect and block sharing of sensitive data, while training reduces human error and reinforces proper handling.
questions.RationaleB: Weakens confidentiality.
questions.RationaleC: Public channels increase exposure.
questions.RationaleD: Removes evidence and reduces detection.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports secure remote administration of Linux servers?
questions.A: SSH with key-based authentication and MFA where supported
questions.RationaleCorrect: SSH encrypts sessions. Key-based auth reduces password theft risk, and MFA further strengthens access. This aligns with best practice for privileged remote access.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports ensuring that security incidents are handled consistently?
questions.A: A documented incident response plan with playbooks and roles
questions.RationaleCorrect: Plans and playbooks standardize actions, reduce confusion, and ensure legal/forensic requirements (evidence handling) are followed, improving outcomes and reducing repeat mistakes.
questions.RationaleB: Inconsistent responses lead to missed containment and errors.
questions.RationaleC: Prevents investigation and accountability.
questions.RationaleD: Chain of custody is essential for evidence credibility.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access due to weak session management in web apps?
questions.A: Short session lifetimes, secure cookies, and server-side session invalidation
questions.RationaleCorrect: Strong session controls limit hijack/reuse windows, reduce token theft exposure, and allow rapid invalidation after suspicious events. Secure cookies reduce XSS-based theft.
questions.RationaleB: URL leakage is common and dangerous.
questions.RationaleC: Maximizes attacker reuse window.
questions.RationaleD: Makes interception easier and undermines confidentiality/integrity.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports protecting an organization from DDoS attacks?
questions.A: DDoS mitigation services, rate limiting, and scalable architecture
questions.RationaleCorrect: DDoS defense requires absorption, filtering, and scaling—often via specialized providers and layered rate limits—so legitimate traffic can still reach services.
questions.RationaleB: Removes a key defensive layer.
questions.RationaleC: Encourages service exhaustion.
questions.RationaleD: Unrelated and increases security risk.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing data remanence on decommissioned SSDs?
questions.A: Cryptographic erase or physical destruction per policy
questions.RationaleCorrect: SSDs may not reliably overwrite due to wear leveling. Crypto erase (destroying encryption keys) or physical destruction ensures data cannot be recovered, addressing remanence risk.
questions.RationaleB: Deletion only removes pointers; data may remain recoverable.
questions.RationaleC: Defrag does not securely erase data.
questions.RationaleD: Permissions don’t remove residual data.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports detecting suspicious lateral movement between internal hosts?
questions.RationaleCorrect: Lateral movement occurs inside the network. Monitoring internal traffic (authentication attempts, SMB/RDP usage, unusual connections) and correlating events is necessary to detect movement after initial compromise.

questions.Question: Which of the following BEST supports preventing unauthorized access to privileged systems from unmanaged endpoints?
questions.A: Conditional access requiring compliant device posture
questions.RationaleCorrect: Conditional access enforces that only devices meeting security standards (managed, patched, encrypted, EDR present) can access sensitive systems. This is core to Zero Trust controls.
